# Today, we will 1) continue practicing with R and R Stuido, and 2) calculate descriptive statistics with Ashley's real data from real primates.

# First, we need to import the data into R Studio from a .csv file.
# I have created three .csv files for you on GitHub for three different primate genera. These are called AHData_InVivoROM_Papio.csv, AHData_InVivoROM_Pan.csv, and AHData_InVivoROM_Macaca.csv . Please use the .csv file that you have been assigned.
# Remember, to import a .csv file into R, we use the function read.csv() .
# We need to tell R which file to import and where to find it. We will use a second funtion, file.choose(), which will show you a pop-up window where you can navigate to the .csv file on your computer (like in Finder).

#For example, if I had a .csv file with data on primate bones that I wanted to import into R, I could type:
bone.dat <- read.csv(file.choose())
# Then I would press Enter and choose my .csv file from the pop-up window.

# Your turn! Import the correct .csv into R using the code below. We're calling this dataset rom.dat. (*Ask me if you want to know why I included the "row.names = NULL" term.)
rom.dat <- read.csv(file.choose(), row.names = NULL)


# Print rom.dat into the Console below. You should now see your data in the Console, and see rom.dat in the Environment tab to the right. How many variables do you see?
print(rom.dat)


# In the last few classes before break, we learned about various descriptive statistics (like mean and standard deviation). Please review your notes and ask questions to remind yourself what these statistics are!

# Mean: To calculate the mean (or average) of a variable, we use the funtion mean() . 
# Remember: to select a single variable from a dataset, we use the $ symbol. For example, if I only want the data for Flexion, I write rom.dat$Flexion .

# Calculate the means for each of the variables in rom.dat. Make sure to write down both your code and the answers below:
# For example:

mean(rom.dat$Flexion)
# Answer: 37.35484 degrees
mean(rom.dat$Extension)
# Answer: 159.2581 degrees
mean(rom.dat$Abduction)
# Answer: 162.2903 degrees
mean(rom.dat$Adduction)
# Answer: 48.12903 degrees
mean(rom.dat$ThighCircumference)
# Answer: 51.90323 cm
mean(rom.dat$ThighLength)
# Answer: 27.19355 cm
mean(rom.dat$BiiliacBreadth, na.rm= TRUE)
# Answer: 39.43333 cm
mean(rom.dat$DistanceBetweenKnees, na.rm= TRUE)
# Answer: 70.82609 cm
mean(rom.dat$BiepicondylarBreadth, na.rm= TRUE)
# Answer: 8.416667 cm
mean(rom.dat$InternalRotation)
# Answer: 36.09677 degrees
mean(rom.dat$ExternalRotation)
# Answer: 77 degrees
```{r}

```

# Median: To calculate the median of a variable, we use the function median() .

# Calculate the medians for each of the variables in rom.dat. Make sure to write down both your code and the answers below:

median(rom.dat$Flexion)
# Answer: 38 degrees
median(rom.dat$Extension)
# Answer: 157 degrees
median(rom.dat$Abduction)
# Answer: 161 degrees
median(rom.dat$Adduction)
# Answer: 48 degrees
median(rom.dat$ThighCircumference)
# Answer: 53 cm
median(rom.dat$ThighLength)
# Answer: 28 cm
median(rom.dat$BiiliacBreadth, na.rm= TRUE)
# Answer: 40 cm
median(rom.dat$DistanceBetweenKnees, na.rm= TRUE)
# Answer: 72 cm
median(rom.dat$BiepicondylarBreadth, na.rm= TRUE)
# Answer: 8 cm
median(rom.dat$InternalRotation)
# Answer: 35 degrees
median(rom.dat$ExternalRotation)
# Answer: 76 degrees
```{r}

```

# Range: To calculate the range of a variable, we use the min() and max() functions to calculate the minimum and maximum values in the dataset. Then, we subtract the min from the max.

# Calculate the ranges for the variables in rom.dat. Make sure to write down both your code and the answers below:
# For example:

range.flex <- max(rom.dat$Flexion) - min(rom.dat$Flexion)
range.flex
# Answer: 43 degrees
range.ext <- max(rom.dat$Extension) - min(rom.dat$Extension)
range.ext
# Answer: 38 degrees
range.abd <- max(rom.dat$Abduction) - min(rom.dat$Abduction)
range.abd
# Answer: 20 degrees
range.add <- max(rom.dat$Adduction) - min(rom.dat$Adduction)
range.add
# Answer: 36 degrees
range.thighcircum <- max(rom.dat$ThighCircumference) - min(rom.dat$ThighCircumference)
range.thighcircum
# Answer: 24 cm
range.thighlen <- max(rom.dat$ThighLength) - min(rom.dat$ThighLength)
range.thighlen
# Answer: 7 cm
range.biiliac <- max(rom.dat$BiiliacBreadth, na.rm=TRUE) - min(rom.dat$BiiliacBreadth, na.rm=TRUE)
range.biiliac
# Answer: 28 cm
range.kneedistance <- max(rom.dat$DistanceBetweenKnees, na.rm=TRUE) - min(rom.dat$DistanceBetweenKnees, na.rm=TRUE)
range.kneedistance
# Answer: 23 cm
range.biepicondylar <- max(rom.dat$BiepicondylarBreadth, na.rm=TRUE) - min(rom.dat$BiepicondylarBreadth, na.rm=TRUE)
range.biepicondylar
# Answer: 9 cm
range.introtation <- max(rom.dat$InternalRotation) - min(rom.dat$ExternalRotation)
range.introtation
# Answer: 10 degrees
range.extrotation <- max(rom.dat$ExternalRotation) - min(rom.dat$ExternalRotation)
range.extrotation
# Answer: 48



# Interquartile Range: To calculate the IQR of a variable, we use the function IQR() .

# Calculate the IQR for each of the variables in rom.dat. Make sure to write down both your code and the answers below:

IQR(rom.dat$Flexion)
# Answer: 15.5 degrees
IQR(rom.dat$Extension)
# Answer: 12 degrees
IQR(rom.dat$Abduction)
# Answer: 6.5 degrees
IQR(rom.dat$Adduction)
# Answer: 11.5 degrees
IQR(rom.dat$ThighCircumference)
# Answer: 12 cm
IQR(rom.dat$ThighLength)
# Answer: 2.5 cm
IQR(rom.dat$BiiliacBreadth, na.rm=TRUE)
# Answer: 9.75 cm
IQR(rom.dat$DistanceBetweenKnees, na.rm=TRUE)
# Answer: 4 cm
IQR(rom.dat$BiepicondylarBreadth, na.rm=TRUE)
# Answer: 3.75 cm
IQR(rom.dat$InternalRotation)
# Answer: 10 degrees
IQR(rom.dat$ExternalRotation)
# Answer: 13.5 degrees

# Now, compare your answers with those of the other person using the same dataset as you!

# Together, work to compile the statistics (mean, median, etc.) of each variable (Extension, Flexion, etc.) into vectors. Then compile these vectors into matrices/dataframes/lists with labels. Your end goal is to have one variable that, when printed, shows you every statistic for every variable.


```{r}
means <- c(mean(rom.dat$Flexion), mean(rom.dat$Extension), mean(rom.dat$Abduction), mean(rom.dat$Adduction), mean(rom.dat$ThighCircumference), mean(rom.dat$ThighLength), mean(rom.dat$BiiliacBreadth, na.rm= TRUE), mean(rom.dat$DistanceBetweenKnees, na.rm= TRUE), mean(rom.dat$BiepicondylarBreadth, na.rm= TRUE), mean(rom.dat$InternalRotation), mean(rom.dat$ExternalRotation))

medians <- c(median(rom.dat$Flexion), median(rom.dat$Extension), median(rom.dat$Abduction), median(rom.dat$Adduction), median(rom.dat$ThighCircumference), median(rom.dat$ThighLength), median(rom.dat$BiiliacBreadth, na.rm= TRUE), median(rom.dat$DistanceBetweenKnees, na.rm= TRUE), median(rom.dat$BiepicondylarBreadth, na.rm= TRUE), median(rom.dat$InternalRotation), median(rom.dat$ExternalRotation))

ranges <- c(range.flex, range.ext, range.abd, range.add, range.thighcircum, range.thighlen, range.biiliac, range.kneedistance, range.biepicondylar, range.introtation, range.extrotation)

iqrs <- c(IQR(rom.dat$Flexion), IQR(rom.dat$Extension), IQR(rom.dat$Abduction), IQR(rom.dat$Adduction), IQR(rom.dat$ThighCircumference), IQR(rom.dat$ThighLength), IQR(rom.dat$BiiliacBreadth), IQR(rom.dat$DistanceBetweenKnees), IQR(rom.dat$BiepicondylarBreadth), IQR(rom.dat$InternalRotation), IQR(rom.dat$ExternalRotation))
```
